author: jochembrouwer
content:
I have some questions regarding FOCIL https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7805. Sorry if I've completely misunderstood some things. But here are some thoughts:

Currently the EL has to do this (excerpt)

```
1. Check whether T is present in B. If T is present, then jump to the next transaction, else continue with next step.

2. Validate T against S.

If T is invalid, then continue to the next transaction.

If T is valid, terminate process and assert block B as invalid.

1. Execute T on state S. Assert that the execution of T fails.
```

I don't understand the last rule. When is this checked? Seems that previously it is checked either T is invalid or T is valid (then the block is invalid). So when is this checked? And why is it checked that the execution of T fails? This still means I have executed my tx, plus I have done a change to the state (bumped nonce of EOA and paid gas). So that means T is valid and thus B is invalid? Even if T fails after executing it?

----

It seems to me that we do not want to execute the IL txs (only check the validity by nonce/balance). So maybe the final rule should be removed?

---- 

There is a cap on the IL list of 8 KiB, which thus means that txs > 8 KiB can be censored. What does this mean? In order to ensure one cannot get censored, it would thus mean the feature we are trying to use fits in a tx <= 8 KiB?

----

It is not entirely clear to me (after reading the EIP a few times) how the IL propagation works. Am I correct that: every IL members can send two ILs (this would be then for slot `N` and slot `N+1`), but these ILs cannot be different (except slot number (?)). So therefore it is possible that the IL lives for block `B` but also for block `B + 1`?

I can see how this makes censorship harder, but a block builder could simply ensure that IL rules are satisfied by just ensuring that the block is full by sending a tx with the gasLimit the current gasLeft of the block and then triggering an INVALID (burning all gas)

author: anderselowsson
content:
> There is a cap on the IL list of 8 KiB, which thus means that txs > 8 KiB can be censored. What does this mean?

If you have a tx with a raw size bigger than 8 KiB, you cannot use the FOCIL services  for censorship resistance on that tx

> It is not entirely clear to me (after reading the EIP a few times) how the IL propagation works. Am I correct that: every IL members can send two ILs (this would be then for slot N and slot N+1), but these ILs cannot be different (except slot number (?)).

Every IL member sends 1 IL. If they send 2, it means they have equivocated. The 2 ILs must then still be propagated, to ensure that everyone is aware of the equivocation, such that both ILs can be ignored.
